Problem:
We consider a quantum system where the wave function \\( \\psi(x, t) \\) evolves according to the Schrödinger equation with a potential function \\( V(x) \\). We study the effect of a measurement operator \\( M \\) applied at time \\( t_1 \\) defined as \\( M \\psi(x, t_1) = e^{-iH\\tau}\\psi(x, t_1) \\) where \\( H \\) is the Hamiltonian of the system and \\( \\tau \\) is a measurement time interval.

If the system state \\( \\psi(x, 0) \\) is evolved to \\( t = t_1 \\) under the Schrödinger equation, and then allowed to continue naturally until time \\( t = T \\) without the application of \\( M \\), will the state \\( \\psi(x, T) \\) be the same as if the measurement operator was applied at \\( t_1 \\)?
Explanation: The application of the measurement operator \\( M \\) changes the state of the system at time \\( t_1 \\) by altering the phase and probabilities of different components according to the Hamiltonian. This change in state would lead to a different evolution path post-\\( t_1 \\), resulting in a different state at time \\( T \\).
